   Assessment and Plan
   89 yo with PMH of alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis,
   pneumonia, and recent d/c from MICU presents with AMS, elevated INR and
   frank blood from her tracheostomy.
   .
   # Blood from trach: Seems from clinical history provided by rehab that
   patient's secretions initially were "blood tinged" and progressed to
   frankly blood over the course of the day on [**12-3**]. Her hematocrit in
   the same time period has decreased from 29-->23.8. Bronchoscopy on
   arrival to the ICU demonstrated bloody secretions which did not clear
   but became progressively bloodier making diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
   most likely diagnosis. However, could also represent lesion near trach
   insertion but this is less likely given bronch findings. In the setting
   of anticoagulation with aspirin and coumadin, needs supportive care
   with reversal of INR and workup for diffuse alveolar hemorrhage.  Given
   FFP, Vitamin K.  Now that INR reversed trach oozing decreased, although
   INR now trending up again, up to 2.5 today. Had 1x tarry black guiac
   positive stool yesterday, today w/heme positive brown stool, but Hct
   stable.  Giving PO Vitamin K 5mg x 3 days.  Unclear why INR continues
   to be supratherapeutic. LFTs wnl.  Platelets wnl. Could be due to IV
   Bactrim?  Needs coagulopathy reversed before can safely return to rehab
   given presenting complaint of alveolar hemorrhage. ANCA negative, anti
   GBM pending.
   - 1x IV vitamin K today, recheck INR tomorrow
   - Active T&S, has new PICC for access
   - antiGBM pending
   - f/u blood cx
   - hold aspirin and coumadin
   - ( to keep in mind: per IP given timeline of 2 weeks s/p trach
   consider CT neck to f/u fistula if bleeding does not stop, HCT does not
   stabilize after correction of coags)
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Initial decompensation likely due to diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, although contribution of underlying pneumonia,
   fluid overload, and baseline [**Known lastname **] disease (?) likely contribute.  Of
   note, during prior admission patient was unsuccessfully extubated twice
   and could not be weaned off the vent after several attempts due to high
   RISBIs and academia.  The patient continued to be ventilator dependent
   at her rehab facility and has failed trach mask and low pressure
   support ventilation during this admission b/c of very low tidal volumes
   (down to 130
s) which improved after pressure support was increased
   from 10 to 20. Patient
s air movement also did improve after albuterol
   nebulizer treatment as per nurse.   Lasix boluses d/c at this point b/c
   of rising Cr.
   - continue treatment for pneumonia as below
   - chlorhexidine
   - albuterol/atrovent MDI  - increase albuterol MDI to Q4h
   - PSV trials, continue to try to wean pressure support and peep as
   tolerated
   .
   # Erythema surrounding PEG site.  Erythema likely combination of
   dermatitis/skin breakdown from pressure of PEG on skin w/some
   cellulitic component. Improved after 3 days on vanco and after padded
   bandage placed between PEG and skin
   -          Continue vanco for 10day course
 last day of antibiotics
   [**12-14**]
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely related to volume depletion secondary to
   blood loss and up titration of lasix at rehab and in MICU as creatinine
   has trended up over the past week per their records. Higher bicarbonate
   level would support volume depletion as well.
   - hold lasix
   - urine lytes, urine Eos
   - spin urine for casts
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - re-check vanco trough tomorrow
   - avoid nephrotoxins as possible
   .
   # L arm hematoma: Likely due to traumatic picc placement.  Does not
   appear to worsening but will follow closely.
   -          warm packs to area
   -          to follow.
   .
   # Paroxysmal afib: The patient was recently started on coumadin at the
   rehab facility with INR now > 5 on coumadin 5 mg daily. CHADs-2 score
   by my calculation only 1 due to age-not clear that patient has h/o
   hypertension or CHF and no documented h/o stroke or DM.
   - hold coumadin and aspirin
   - consider full dose aspirin for anticoagulation once out of acute
   episode
   - patient typically bradycardic per prior d/c summary, not on rate
   control meds
   .
   # Abdominal distension: NTTP.  Resolved with bowel movement.  Had CXR
   several days ago with what appeared to be a large gas bubble in the
   stomach. Repeat  KUB showed no acute process, LFTs and lipase benign.
   When attempt to draw back on PEG no air noted.
   .
   # Recent Stenotrophomonas VAP: Continue bactrim 250 mg IV q8h, stop
   date 12/5 per prior d/c summary
   -bactrim may account for supratheraputic INR
   -role in VAP leading to pulm hemorrhage unclear
   .
   # Alzheimer's/? altered mental status: Low functioning at baseline.
   Delirium given acute event on top of usual dementia not improving
   situation. To continue home meds when using PEG tube (await KUB
   result).
   .
   # PPx: Increase PPI to [**Hospital1 **], d/c heparin SQ since INR 2.0. Continue
   pneumoboots. Change bowel regimen to prn b/c of diarrhea.
   .
   #FEN: re-start TF as per nutrition.
   .
   # Code: full, confirmed with son [**Name (NI) 6287**] [**Name (NI) 904**] who is HCP
   .
   # Access: Right-sided PICC (placed at [**Hospital1 54**] during previous admission).
   To be removed once Left picc placed by IR
   .
   # Communication: With patient and son [**Name (NI) 6287**] [**Known lastname 6767**]([**Telephone/Fax (1) 6768**] cell
   .

Summary:

The patient is an 89-year-old woman with a history of Alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis, pneumonia, and recent tracheostomy. She was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, and bleeding from her tracheostomy site. She has a history of failed extubation attempts and is currently ventilator-dependent. Her INR is supratherapeutic, and she is receiving IV Vitamin K and FFP. She has a PICC line in place, and her laboratory results show a low platelet count and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage: The patient's bleeding from her tracheostomy site and bloody secretions suggest diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, which is a life-threatening complication.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's supratherapeutic INR and low platelet count suggest coagulopathy, which can increase the risk of bleeding and other complications.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's history of pneumonia and current respiratory failure suggest a high risk of further complications, such as respiratory failure and sepsis.
4. Urosepsis: The patient's history of urosepsis and current urinary tract infection (UTI) suggest a high risk of further complications, such as sepsis and kidney injury.
5. Abdominal distension: The patient's abdominal distension and constipation suggest a high risk of further complications, such as bowel obstruction and perforation.
6. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation: The patient's history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and current supratherapeutic INR suggest a high risk of further complications, such as stroke and cardiac arrest.
7. Lymphopenia: The patient's low lymphocyte count suggests a high risk of infections and other complications.
8. Erythema surrounding PEG site: The patient's erythema surrounding her PEG site suggests a high risk of further complications, such as cellulitis and abscess formation.
9. L arm hematoma: The patient's L arm hematoma suggests a high risk of further complications, such as compartment syndrome and nerve damage.
10. Renal failure: The patient's history of renal failure and current elevated creatinine levels suggest a high risk of further complications, such as acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's coagulopathy and adjust her anticoagulant therapy as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's pneumonia and adjust her antibiotic therapy as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's urosepsis and adjust her antibiotic therapy as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's abdominal distension and adjust her bowel regimen as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and adjust her anticoagulant therapy as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's lymphopenia and adjust her antibiotic therapy as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's erythema surrounding PEG site and adjust her antibiotic therapy as needed.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's L arm hematoma and adjust her anticoagulant therapy as needed.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's renal failure and adjust her antihypertensive therapy as needed.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and aggressive management of her various medical complications to prevent further deterioration and improve her outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   89 yo with PMH of alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis,
   pneumonia, and recent d/c from MICU presents with AMS, elevated INR and
   frank blood from her tracheostomy.
   .
   # Blood from trach: Seems from clinical history provided by rehab that
   patient's secretions initially were "blood tinged" and progressed to
   frankly blood over the course of the day on [**12-3**]. Her hematocrit in
   the same time period has decreased from 29-->23.8. Bronchoscopy on
   arrival to the ICU demonstrated bloody secretions which did not clear
   but became progressively bloodier making diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
   most likely diagnosis. However, could also represent lesion near trach
   insertion but this is less likely given bronch findings. In the setting
   of anticoagulation with aspirin and coumadin, needs supportive care
   with reversal of INR and workup for diffuse alveolar hemorrhage.  Given
   FFP, Vitamin K PO, and then Vitamin K IV for refractory elevated INR.
   Once INR reversed trach oozing decreased. Needs coagulopathy reversed
   before can safely return to rehab given presenting complaint of
   alveolar hemorrhage. ANCA negative, anti GBM pending.
   - 1x IV vitamin K today, recheck INR tomorrow
   - Active T&S, has new PICC for access
   - antiGBM pending
   - f/u blood cx
   - hold aspirin and coumadin
   - ( to keep in mind: per IP given timeline of 2 weeks s/p trach
   consider CT neck to f/u fistula if bleeding does not stop, HCT does not
   stabilize after correction of coags)
   .
   # Anemia: Hct drop x3 since admission. Transfused 3x with 2U of blood.
   Initial drop explained by DAH. Hct trended down after 2U PRBC given. In
   setting of melena and another Hct drop to 22.8, transfused additional
   2U 2 d ago.  Now w/additional Hct drop to 20.7 today w/out clear
   explanation.  Hemolysis labs sent.  Moderate hematoma in L arm and
   possibly anterior chest, but not enough to explain Hct drop.
   Possibility of spontaneous intraperitoneal or retroperitoneal
   hemorrhage?
   -          Non-contrast abd CT
   -          f/u hemolysis labs
   -          follow hematoma size
   -          Post transfusion Hct, Q12h Hcts
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely related to volume depletion secondary to
   blood loss and up titration of lasix at rehab and in MICU as creatinine
   has trended up over the past week per their records.  UOP had been poor
   and unresponsive to lasix but has improved over last 12 h as per
   nursing.  Higher bicarbonate level and FeUREA of 34% would support
   volume depletion as well.  UA w/few eos, rare hyaline casts reported.
   Did have hematuria, but difficult to interpret in setting of indwelling
   foley, elevated INR, and likely UTI. Anti-GBM pending.
   - hold lasix
   - pm lytes
   - spin urine for casts (team to do, not lab)
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins as possible
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Initial decompensation likely due to diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, although contribution of underlying pneumonia,
   fluid overload, and baseline [**Known lastname **] disease (?) likely contribute.  Of
   note, during prior admission patient was unsuccessfully extubated twice
   and could not be weaned off the vent after several attempts due to high
   RISBIs and academia.  The patient continued to be ventilator dependent
   at her rehab facility and has failed trach mask and low pressure
   support ventilation during this admission b/c of very low tidal volumes
   (down to 130
s) which improved after pressure support was increased
   from 10 to 20. Patient
s air movement also did improve after albuterol
   nebulizer treatment as per nurse.   Lasix boluses d/c at this point b/c
   of rising Cr.  Increased albuterol MDI to Q4h yesterday.
   - continue treatment for pneumonia as below
   - chlorhexidine
   - albuterol/atrovent MDI  -
   - PSV trials, continue to try to wean pressure support and peep as
   tolerated
   .
   # Erythema surrounding PEG site.  Erythema likely combination of
   dermatitis/skin breakdown from pressure of PEG on skin w/some
   cellulitic component. Improved after 3 days on vanco and after padded
   bandage placed between PEG and skin
   -          Continue vanco for 10day course

   .
   # L arm hematoma: Likely due to traumatic picc placement.  Does not

   # Paroxysmal afib: The patient was recently started on coumadin at the

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 89-year-old female with a complex medical history, including Alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis, pneumonia, and recent discharge from the MICU. The patient presents with acute mental status changes, elevated INR, and frank blood from her tracheostomy.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 7.5 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 20.7%
* Platelet count: 249 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 10.8 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 34%
* Calcium: 8.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.6 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.9 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL

The patient has been diagnosed with diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, which is likely due to anticoagulation with aspirin and coumadin. The patient has also been diagnosed with acute renal failure, which is likely related to volume depletion secondary to blood loss and up-titration of lasix.

The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with a requirement for mechanical ventilation. The patient has also been diagnosed with pneumonia, which is being treated with antibiotics.

The patient has a history of abdominal distension, which has resolved with a bowel movement. However, the patient's recent stool culture showed Stenotrophomonas, which is being treated with Bactrim.

The patient's nutritional status is compromised, with a requirement for total parenteral nutrition (TPN). The patient's glycemic control is also a concern, with a recent blood glucose level of 161 mg/dL.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
* Acute renal failure
* Pneumonia
* Abdominal distension
* Stenotrophomonas VAP
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Hypocalcemia
* Hypomagnesemia
* Hyperphosphatemia

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Reversal of INR with vitamin K
* Supportive care for diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
* Treatment of pneumonia with antibiotics
* Management of acute renal failure with fluid restriction and medication adjustments
* Monitoring of abdominal distension and bowel function
* Nutritional support with TPN
* Glycemic control with insulin therapy
* Monitoring of blood glucose levels
* Treatment of Stenotrophomonas VAP with Bactrim

The patient's code status is full code, and the patient is being cared for in the ICU with mechanical ventilation and other life-sustaining therapies.

Summary:

The patient is an 89-year-old female with chronic ventilatory failure and atrial fibrillation, re-admitted to the ICU with significant hemoptysis and persistent respiratory failure. She has worsening renal failure, anemia, and peripheral edema. She is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy tube in place. Her laboratory results show acute kidney injury, anemia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. She has a history of dementia, atrial fibrillation, and bacteremia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is acute and not associated with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). She requires close monitoring and management of her respiratory status.
2. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is worsening, and she has acute kidney injury. Close monitoring of her renal function and management of her fluid status are necessary.
3. Anemia: The patient has acute anemia secondary to blood loss, which may be related to pulmonary hemorrhage. Close monitoring of her hemoglobin levels and transfusion requirements are necessary.
4. Bleeding: The patient has ongoing bleeding, which may be related to her atrial fibrillation and anticoagulation therapy. Close monitoring of her bleeding risk and management of her anticoagulation therapy are necessary.
5. Infection: The patient has a history of bacteremia and may be at risk for further infections. Close monitoring of her infection risk and management of her antibiotic therapy are necessary.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation and may be at risk for further cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias. Close monitoring of her cardiovascular status and management of her atrial fibrillation are necessary.
7. Neurological complications: The patient has dementia and may be at risk for further neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke. Close monitoring of her neurological status and management of her dementia are necessary.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of her respiratory, renal, and cardiovascular status, as well as close monitoring of her bleeding risk and infection risk.

   Assessment and Plan
   89 yo with PMH of alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis,
   pneumonia, and recent d/c from MICU presents with AMS, elevated INR and
   frank blood from her tracheostomy.
   .
   # Blood from trach: Seems from clinical history provided by rehab that
   patient's secretions initially were "blood tinged" and progressed to
   frankly blood over the course of the day on [**12-3**]. Her hematocrit in
   the same time period has decreased from 29-->23.8. Bronchoscopy on
   arrival to the ICU demonstrated bloody secretions which did not clear
   but became progressively bloodier making diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
   most likely diagnosis. However, could also represent lesion near trach
   insertion but this is less likely given bronch findings. Held aspirin
   and coumadin, reversal of INR with  FFP, Vitamin K PO, and then Vitamin
   K IV .  Once INR reversed trach oozing decreased. ANCA negative, anti
   GBM pending.
   - INR 1.4
   - Active T&S, has new PICC for access
   - antiGBM pending
   - f/u blood cx
   - hold aspirin and coumadin
   - ( to keep in mind: per IP given timeline of 2 weeks s/p trach
   consider CT neck to f/u fistula if bleeding does not stop, HCT does not
   stabilize after correction of coags)
   - wean vent as tolerated
   .
   # Anemia: Hct drop x3 since admission. Transfused 3x with 2U of blood.
   Initial drop explained by DAH. Hct did not bump appropriately, found to
   have melena x1 and repeatedly giauac pos stool. Hemolysis labs sent.
   Enlarging hematoma in L arm, axilla,  and anterior chest, but likely
   source of  Hct drop.  Possibility of spontaneous intraperitoneal or
   retroperitoneal hemorrhage r/o with CT abd yesterday
   -  hemolysis labs negative

Summary:

The patient is an 89-year-old woman with a history of Alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis, pneumonia, and recent discharge from the MICU. She was admitted to the ICU with AMS, elevated INR, and frank blood from her tracheostomy. The patient has multiple comorbidities, including anemia, acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and PEG site complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH): The patient's bloody secretions and decreasing Hct levels suggest DAH, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure.
2. Hemolysis: The patient's Hct drop and melena suggest hemolysis, which may be related to the DAH or other underlying conditions.
3. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's rising creatinine levels and fluid overload may indicate ARF, which may be exacerbated by her underlying kidney disease and recent antibiotic use.
4. PEG Site Complications: The patient's erythema and pus around the PEG site may indicate cellulitis or skin breakdown, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
5. Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation (PAF): The patient's recent start of coumadin and INR levels above 5 may indicate PAF, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Porcelain Gallbladder: The patient's CT abdomen revealed a porcelain gallbladder, which may be associated with adenocarcinoma.
7. Stenotrophomonas VAP: The patient's recent VAP and treatment with Bactrim may indicate a risk for further complications.
8. Alzheimer's Disease: The patient's low functioning at baseline and altered mental status may indicate worsening of her dementia, which may require further evaluation and treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue treatment for DAH, including bronchoscopy and aspiration of bloody secretions.
2. Monitor the patient's Hct levels and consider further evaluation and treatment for hemolysis.
3. Continue treatment for ARF, including fluid management and renal dose medications.
4. Continue treatment for PEG site complications, including antibiotic therapy and wound care.
5. Monitor the patient's INR levels and consider further evaluation and treatment for PAF.
6. Consider further evaluation and treatment for porcelain gallbladder, including cholecystectomy.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider further treatment for VAP, including antibiotics and respiratory support.
8. Consider further evaluation and treatment for Alzheimer's disease, including medications and behavioral interventions.

Summary:

The patient is an 89-year-old woman with a history of Alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis, pneumonia, and recent discharge from the MICU. She presents to the ICU with altered mental status, elevated INR, and frank blood from her tracheostomy. The patient has a history of bleeding from her tracheostomy site, which has worsened over time. She has also developed anemia, acute renal failure, and peripheral edema.

The patient's current condition is critical, with ongoing bleeding from her tracheostomy site, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. She requires ongoing support with oxygen therapy, mechanical ventilation, and vasopressors. Her nutritional needs are being met through total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and enteral nutrition (TF).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH): The patient's bleeding from her tracheostomy site and respiratory failure suggest a possible diagnosis of DAH. This could be exacerbated by her anticoagulation therapy with aspirin and coumadin.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and she has a history of volume depletion. This could be worsened by her ongoing bleeding and respiratory failure.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely secondary to blood loss, and her hematocrit has dropped significantly since admission. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of her anemia.
4. Peripheral edema: The patient's peripheral edema is likely secondary to her acute renal failure and volume overload.
5. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's erythema surrounding her PEG site and anterior chest wall mass suggest impaired skin integrity.
6. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation: The patient's recent initiation of coumadin may have contributed to her elevated INR and atrial fibrillation.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's recent melena and hematuria suggest possible gastrointestinal bleeding, which could be exacerbated by her anticoagulation therapy.
8. Infection: The patient's recent Stenotrophomonas VAP and ongoing bleeding from her tracheostomy site suggest possible infection.
9. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and possible DAH may be contributing to her neurological complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding from her tracheostomy site and respiratory failure closely.
2. Reassess the patient's anticoagulation therapy and consider holding aspirin and coumadin until further evaluation.
3. Continue to support the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
4. Consider further evaluation of the patient's anemia, including hemolysis labs and possible transfusion.
5. Monitor the patient's peripheral edema and consider diuretic therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's erythema surrounding her PEG site and anterior chest wall mass.
7. Consider further evaluation of the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding, including endoscopy and possible transfusion.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and consider further evaluation of her possible VAP.
9. Consider further evaluation of the patient's neurological complications, including possible imaging studies and consultation with neurology.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 89-year-old woman with a history of Alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis, pneumonia, and recent discharge from the MICU. She presents with acute mental status changes, elevated INR, and frank blood from her tracheostomy.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH): The patient has bloody secretions and a decreased hematocrit, which suggests DAH.
2. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit has dropped three times since admission, and she has received multiple blood transfusions.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has a rising creatinine level and a history of volume depletion, which suggests acute renal failure.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent and has a history of failed extubation attempts.
5. PEG Site Complications: The patient has erythema and pus around the PEG site, which may be due to dermatitis, skin breakdown, or cellulitis.
6. L Arm Hematoma: The patient has a large hematoma in her left arm, which may be due to traumatic PICC placement.
7. Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has an elevated INR and is taking coumadin, which may contribute to her arrhythmia.
8. Abdominal Distension: The patient has a history of abdominal distension, which may be due to intraperitoneal bleeding or a large gas bubble in the stomach.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Further bleeding from the PEG site or tracheostomy
2. Continued decline in renal function
3. Respiratory failure or worsening of respiratory symptoms
4. Further development of anemia or bleeding
5. Complications related to the PICC line, such as infection or dislodgement
6. Development of arrhythmias or cardiac complications
7. Further abdominal distension or bowel obstruction
8. Infection or sepsis related to the tracheostomy or PEG site

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Continued treatment for pneumonia and respiratory failure
2. Management of anemia and bleeding
3. Monitoring of renal function and adjusting treatment as necessary
4. Management of PEG site complications
5. Monitoring of the PICC line and adjusting treatment as necessary
6. Treatment for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
7. Monitoring of abdominal distension and adjusting treatment as necessary

The patient's code status is full code, and she is currently receiving ICU-level care.

* The patient's laboratory results show acute kidney injury, anemia, and peripheral edema, among other abnormalities.
* The patient has a history of dementia, atrial fibrillation, bacteremia, and respiratory failure, which are likely contributing to their current condition.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and the risk of further respiratory failure is high.
* Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and acute kidney injury increase the risk of sepsis.
* Bleeding: The patient's anemia and history of bleeding may increase the risk of further bleeding.
* DVT: The patient's immobility and central venous catheters increase the risk of DVT.
* VAP: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation increase the risk of VAP.
* Infection: The patient's multiple comorbidities and acute complications increase the risk of infection.

Given the patient's complex condition, it is essential to closely monitor their vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to identify any potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent further deterioration.

   Assessment and Plan
   89 yo with PMH of alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis,
   pneumonia, and recent d/c from MICU presents with AMS, elevated INR and
   frank blood from her tracheostomy.
   .
   # Blood from trach: Seems from clinical history provided by rehab that
   patient's secretions initially were "blood tinged" and progressed to
   frankly blood over the course of the day on [**12-3**]. Her hematocrit in
   the same time period has decreased from 29-->23.8. Bronchoscopy on
   arrival to the ICU demonstrated bloody secretions which did not clear
   but became progressively bloodier making diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
   most likely diagnosis. However, could also represent lesion near trach
   insertion but this is less likely given bronch findings. In the setting
   of anticoagulation with aspirin and coumadin, needs supportive care
   with reversal of INR and workup for diffuse alveolar hemorrhage.  Given
   FFP, Vitamin K PO, and then Vitamin K IV for refractory elevated INR.
   Once INR reversed trach oozing decreased. Needs coagulopathy reversed
   before can safely return to rehab given presenting complaint of
   alveolar hemorrhage. ANCA negative, anti GBM pending.
   - 1x IV vitamin K today, recheck INR tomorrow
   - Active T&S, has new PICC for access
   - antiGBM pending
   - f/u blood cx
   - hold aspirin and coumadin
   - ( to keep in mind: per IP given timeline of 2 weeks s/p trach
   consider CT neck to f/u fistula if bleeding does not stop, HCT does not
   stabilize after correction of coags)
   .
   # Anemia: Hct drop x3 since admission. Transfused 3x with 2U of blood.
   Initial drop explained by DAH. Hct trended down after 2U PRBC given. In
   setting of melena and another Hct drop to 22.8, transfused additional
   2U 2 d ago.  Now w/additional Hct drop to 20.7 today w/out clear
   explanation.  Hemolysis labs sent.  Moderate hematoma in L arm and
   possibly anterior chest, but not enough to explain Hct drop.
   Possibility of spontaneous intraperitoneal or retroperitoneal
   hemorrhage?
   -          Non-contrast abd CT
   -          f/u hemolysis labs
   -          follow hematoma size
   -          Post transfusion Hct, Q12h Hcts
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely related to volume depletion secondary to
   blood loss and up titration of lasix at rehab and in MICU as creatinine
   has trended up over the past week per their records.  UOP had been poor
   and unresponsive to lasix but has improved over last 12 h as per
   nursing.  Higher bicarbonate level and FeUREA of 34% would support
   volume depletion as well.  UA w/few eos, rare hyaline casts reported.
   Did have hematuria, but difficult to interpret in setting of indwelling
   foley, elevated INR, and likely UTI. Anti-GBM pending.
   - hold lasix
   - pm lytes
   - spin urine for casts (team to do, not lab)
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins as possible
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Initial decompensation likely due to diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, although contribution of underlying pneumonia,
   fluid overload, and baseline [**Known lastname **] disease (?) likely contribute.  Of
   note, during prior admission patient was unsuccessfully extubated twice
   and could not be weaned off the vent after several attempts due to high
   RISBIs and academia.  The patient continued to be ventilator dependent
   at her rehab facility and has failed trach mask and low pressure
   support ventilation during this admission b/c of very low tidal volumes
   (down to 130
s) which improved after pressure support was increased
   from 10 to 20. Patient
s air movement also did improve after albuterol
   nebulizer treatment as per nurse.   Lasix boluses d/c at this point b/c
   of rising Cr.  Increased albuterol MDI to Q4h yesterday.
   - continue treatment for pneumonia as below
   - chlorhexidine
   - albuterol/atrovent MDI  -
   - PSV trials, continue to try to wean pressure support and peep as
   tolerated
   .
   # Erythema surrounding PEG site.  Erythema likely combination of
   dermatitis/skin breakdown from pressure of PEG on skin w/some
   cellulitic component. Improved after 3 days on vanco and after padded
   bandage placed between PEG and skin
   -          Continue vanco for 10day course
 last day of antibiotics
   [**12-14**]
   .
   # L arm hematoma: Likely due to traumatic picc placement.  Does not
   appear to worsening but will follow closely.  Anterior chest wall mass
   likely a continuation of same process.
   -          warm packs to area
   -          to follow.
   .
   # Paroxysmal afib: The patient was recently started on coumadin at the
   rehab facility with INR now > 5 on coumadin 5 mg daily. CHADs-2 score
   by my calculation only 1 due to age-not clear that patient has h/o
   hypertension or CHF and no documented h/o stroke or DM.
   - hold coumadin and aspirin
   - consider full dose aspirin for anticoagulation once out of acute
   episode
   - patient typically bradycardic per prior d/c summary, not on rate
   control meds
   .
   # Abdominal distension: NTTP.  Resolved with bowel movement.  Had CXR
   several days ago with what appeared to be a large gas bubble in the
   stomach. Repeat  KUB showed no acute process, LFTs and lipase benign.
   When attempt to draw back on PEG no air noted.  In setting of Hct drop
   and spontaneous alveolar bleeding, could possibly due to
   intraperitoneal bleeding?
   - f/u CT result
   .
   # Recent Stenotrophomonas VAP: Bactrim 250 mg IV q8h, stop date today
   per prior d/c summary.
   .
   # Alzheimer's/? altered mental status: Low functioning at baseline.
   Delirium given acute event on top of usual dementia not improving
   situation. To continue home meds when using PEG tube (await KUB
   result).
   .
   # PPx: Increased PPI to [**Hospital1 **], d/c heparin SQ since INR 2.0. Continue
   pneumoboots. Change bowel regimen to prn b/c of diarrhea.
   .
   #FEN: re-start TF as per nutrition.
   .
   # Code: full, confirmed with son [**Name (NI) 6287**] [**Name (NI) 904**] who is HCP
   .
   # Access: Right-sided PICC (placed at [**Hospital1 54**] during previous admission).
   To be removed once Left picc placed by IR
   .
   # Communication: With patient and son [**Name (NI) 6287**] [**Known lastname 6767**]([**Telephone/Fax (1) 6768**] cell
   .
   # Dispo: ICU level care given vent requirement

   89 yo with PMH of alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis,
   pneumonia, and recent d/c from MICU presents with AMS, elevated INR and
   frank blood from her tracheostomy.
   .
   # Blood from trach: Seems from clinical history provided by rehab that
   patient's secretions initially were "blood tinged" and progressed to
   frankly blood over the course of the day on [**12-3**]. Her hematocrit in
   the same time period has decreased from 29-->23.8. Bronchoscopy on
   arrival to the ICU demonstrated bloody secretions which did not clear
   but became progressively bloodier making diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
   most likely diagnosis. However, could also represent lesion near trach
   insertion but this is less likely given bronch findings. In the setting
   of anticoagulation with aspirin and coumadin, needs supportive care
   with reversal of INR and workup for diffuse alveolar hemorrhage.  Given
   FFP, Vitamin K PO, and then Vitamin K IV for refractory elevated INR.
   Once INR reversed trach oozing decreased. Needs coagulopathy reversed
   before can safely return to rehab given presenting complaint of
   alveolar hemorrhage. ANCA negative, anti GBM pending.
   - 1x IV vitamin K today, recheck INR tomorrow
   - Active T&S, has new PICC for access
   - antiGBM pending
   - f/u blood cx
   - hold aspirin and coumadin
   - ( to keep in mind: per IP given timeline of 2 weeks s/p trach
   consider CT neck to f/u fistula if bleeding does not stop, HCT does not
   stabilize after correction of coags)
   .
   # Anemia: Hct drop x3 since admission. Transfused 3x with 2U of blood.
   Initial drop explained by DAH. Hct trended down after 2U PRBC given. In
   setting of melena and another Hct drop to 22.8, transfused additional
   2U 2 d ago.  Now w/additional Hct drop to 20.7 today w/out clear
   explanation.  Hemolysis labs sent.  Moderate hematoma in L arm and
   possibly anterior chest, but not enough to explain Hct drop.
   Possibility of spontaneous intraperitoneal or retroperitoneal
   hemorrhage?
   -          Non-contrast abd CT
   -          f/u hemolysis labs
   -          follow hematoma size
   -          Post transfusion Hct, Q12h Hcts
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely related to volume depletion secondary to
   blood loss and up titration of lasix at rehab and in MICU as creatinine
   has trended up over the past week per their records.  UOP had been poor
   and unresponsive to lasix but has improved over last 12 h as per
   nursing.  Higher bicarbonate level and FeUREA of 34% would support
   volume depletion as well.  UA w/few eos, rare hyaline casts reported.

   - avoid nephrotoxins as possible

Summary:

The patient is an 89-year-old woman with a history of Alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis, pneumonia, and recent discharge from the MICU. She is currently in the ICU due to acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and anemia secondary to blood loss. She has a tracheostomy with frank blood from the tracheostomy site, which is likely due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. She has also developed an erythematous rash around the PEG site, which is being treated with vancomycin. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently on aspirin and coumadin, which has resulted in an elevated INR.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage: The patient's tracheostomy site is bleeding, and her bronchoscopy revealed bloody secretions. This could be due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, which is a life-threatening condition.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine has been trending up over the past week, and she has a history of volume depletion secondary to blood loss and diuretic use.
3. Anemia: The patient has a significant anemia, which could be due to blood loss, hemolysis, or other causes.
4. Erythema around PEG site: The patient has developed an erythematous rash around the PEG site, which could be due to dermatitis, skin breakdown, or cellulitis.
5. L arm hematoma: The patient has a moderate-sized hematoma in her left arm, which could be due to traumatic PICC placement.
6. Abdominal distension: The patient has developed abdominal distension, which could be due to bowel obstruction, constipation, or other causes.
7. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which could be due to underlying cardiac disease or other causes.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, which could be due to pneumonia, fluid overload, or other causes.
9. Sepsis: The patient has a history of urosepsis and bacteremia, which could be due to underlying infections.
10. Hemoptysis: The patient has developed hemoptysis, which could be due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, bronchiectasis, or other causes.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's tracheostomy site and bleeding.
2. Consider bronchoscopy to further evaluate the patient's lung disease.
3. Continue to treat the patient's pneumonia with antibiotics and supportive care.
4. Monitor the patient's creatinine and adjust diuretic therapy as necessary.
5. Continue to transfuse blood products as necessary to treat the patient's anemia.
6. Monitor the patient's erythematous rash around the PEG site and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Consider imaging studies to evaluate the patient's abdominal distension.
8. Monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust treatment as necessary.
9. Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.

   89 yo with PMH of alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis,
   pneumonia, and recent d/c from MICU presents with AMS, elevated INR and
   frank blood from her tracheostomy.
   .
   # Blood from trach: Seems from clinical history provided by rehab that
   patient's secretions initially were "blood tinged" and progressed to
   frankly blood over the course of the day on [**12-3**]. Her hematocrit in
   the same time period has decreased from 29-->23.8. Bronchoscopy on
   arrival to the ICU demonstrated bloody secretions which did not clear
   but became progressively bloodier making diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
   most likely diagnosis. However, could also represent lesion near trach
   insertion but this is less likely given bronch findings. Held aspirin
   and coumadin, reversal of INR with  FFP, Vitamin K PO, and then Vitamin
   K IV .  Once INR reversed trach oozing decreased. ANCA negative, anti
   GBM pending.
   - INR 1.4
   - Active T&S, has new PICC for access
   - antiGBM pending
   - f/u blood cx
   - hold aspirin and coumadin
   - ( to keep in mind: per IP given timeline of 2 weeks s/p trach
   consider CT neck to f/u fistula if bleeding does not stop, HCT does not
   stabilize after correction of coags)
   - wean vent as tolerated
   .
   # Anemia: Hct drop x3 since admission. Transfused 3x with 2U of blood.
   Initial drop explained by DAH. Hct did not bump appropriately, found to
   have melena x1 and repeatedly giauac pos stool. Hemolysis labs sent.
   Enlarging hematoma in L arm, axilla,  and anterior chest, but likely
   source of  Hct drop.  Possibility of spontaneous intraperitoneal or
   retroperitoneal hemorrhage r/o with CT abd yesterday
   -  hemolysis labs negative
   -          follow hematoma size
   -          s/p 1 U pRBC  [**Date range (1) 6895**]
   -          Post transfusion Hct, Q12h Hcts
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely related to volume depletion secondary to
   blood loss and up titration of lasix at rehab and in MICU as creatinine
   has trended up over the past week per their records Higher bicarbonate
   level and FeUREA of 34% would support volume depletion as well.  UA
   w/few eos, rare hyaline casts reported.  Did have hematuria, but
   difficult to interpret in setting of indwelling foley, elevated INR,
   and likely UTI. Anti-GBM pending.
   - hold lasix
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins as possible
   -Cr responding well to blood transfusion
   - staghorn R kidney stone noted on CT could be contributing
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Initial decompensation likely due to diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, although contribution of underlying pneumonia,
   fluid overload, and baseline [**Known lastname **] disease (?) likely contribute.  Of
   note, during prior admission patient was unsuccessfully extubated twice
   and could not be weaned off the vent after several attempts due to high
   RISBIs  and acidemia.  The patient continued to be ventilator dependent
   at her rehab facility and has failed trach mask and low pressure
   support ventilation during this admission b/c of very low tidal volumes
   (down to 130
s) which improved after pressure support was increased
   from 10 to 20. Patient
s air movement also did improve after albuterol
   nebulizer treatment as per nurse.   Lasix boluses d/c at this point b/c
   of rising Cr.  Increased albuterol MDI to Q4h yesterday.
   - continue treatment for pneumonia as below
   - chlorhexidine
   - albuterol/atrovent MDI  -
   - PSV trials, continue to try to wean pressure support and peep as
   tolerated
   .
   # PEG site.  Erythema/ Pus around peg likely combination of
   dermatitis/skin breakdown from pressure of PEG on skin w/some
   cellulitic component. Improved after 3 days on vanco and after padded
   bandage placed between PEG and skin
   - increased Pus this am
   - Continue vanco for 10day course
 last day of antibiotics [**12-14**]
   - CT showed Peg balloon eroded into gastric wall, likely source of
   melena. Repositioned by IP. OK for meds but not feeds so dobhoff
   inserted.
   .
   # L arm hematoma: Likely due to traumatic picc placement.  Does not
   appear to worsening but will follow closely.  Anterior chest wall mass
   likely a continuation of same process.
   -          warm packs to area
   -          to follow.
   .
   # Paroxysmal afib: The patient was recently started on coumadin at the
   rehab facility with INR now > 5 on coumadin 5 mg daily. CHADs-2 score
   by my calculation only 1 due to age-not clear that patient has h/o
   hypertension or CHF and no documented h/o stroke or DM.
   - hold coumadin and aspirin
   - consider full dose aspirin for anticoagulation once out of acute
   episode
   - patient typically bradycardic per prior d/c summary, not on rate
   control meds
   .
   # Abdominal distension: NTTP.  Resolved with bowel movement.  Had CXR
   several days ago with what appeared to be a large gas bubble in the
   stomach. Repeat  KUB showed no acute process, LFTs and lipase benign.
   When attempt to draw back on PEG no air noted.  In setting of Hct drop
   and spontaneous alveolar bleeding, CT abd obtained, no evidence of RP
   bleed
   .
   # porcelain gallbladder: noted on CT abd, associated with
   adenocarcinoma 25% of time. [**Month (only) 60**] need further work up out of ICU
   setting.
   .
   # Recent Stenotrophomonas VAP: Bactrim 250 mg IV q8h, stop date [**12-8**]
   per prior d/c summary.
   .
   # Alzheimer's/? altered mental status: Low functioning at baseline.
   Delirium given acute event on top of usual dementia not improving
   situation. To continue home meds when using PEG tube (await KUB
   result).
   .
   # PPx: Increased PPI to [**Hospital1 **], d/c heparin SQ since INR 2.0. Continue
   pneumoboots. Change bowel regimen to prn b/c of diarrhea.
   .
   #FEN: re-start TF as per nutrition.
   .
   # Code: full, family meeting [**12-9**], family considering DNR
   .
   # Access: Right-sided PICC (placed at [**Hospital1 54**] during previous admission).
   To be removed once Left picc placed by IR
   .
   # Communication: With patient and son [**Name (NI) 6287**] [**Known lastname 6767**]([**Telephone/Fax (1) 6768**] cell
   .

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Hemorrhage: The patient has a history of bleeding from the tracheostomy site, and the recent CT scan showed a large hematoma in the left arm, axilla, and anterior chest wall. The patient is at risk of further bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and organ failure.
2. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine level has been trending upwards, and the patient has a history of fluid overload and hypovolemia. ARF could worsen the patient's condition and increase the risk of mortality.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent and has a history of pneumonia, fluid overload, and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. The patient's respiratory status could deteriorate further, leading to respiratory failure and increased mortality.
4. Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia, UTI, and VAP, and is at risk of developing further infections. Infections could worsen the patient's condition and increase the risk of mortality.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of melena and gastrointestinal bleeding, which could worsen the patient's condition and increase the risk of mortality.
6. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is at risk of developing further cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or stroke.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient has a history of altered mental status and is at risk of developing further neurological complications, such as seizures or cerebral edema.
8. Hemolysis: The patient's hemoglobin level has been trending downwards, and the patient is at risk of developing hemolysis, which could worsen the patient's condition and increase the risk of mortality.

To mitigate these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored and managed in the ICU. The patient's bleeding should be controlled, and the patient should be treated for any underlying infections. The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored, and the patient should be weaned off the ventilator as tolerated. The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding should be treated, and the patient should be monitored for any signs of cardiovascular or neurological complications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9Â°C, heart rate of 80 bpm, and blood pressure of 111/46 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 95% on a FiO2 of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results indicate acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 38 mg/dL. The patient's hemoglobin level is 10.5 g/dL, and platelet count is 192 K/uL.

The patient's imaging studies show evidence of a large left axillary hematoma, which is expanding. The patient's respiratory support is provided through a tracheostomy tube with a ventilator mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow.

The patient's nutritional support is provided through a PEG tube with gravity feeding, and the patient's glycemic control is being monitored. The patient is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's medical history includes dementia, atrial fibrillation, bacteremia, respiratory failure, and hemoptysis. The patient's family has been informed of the patient's condition and has made the decision to make the patient's code status DNR (do not resuscitate).

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Progressive respiratory failure requiring increased ventilator support or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Worsening of acute kidney injury leading to the need for renal replacement therapy (RRT).
3. Hemorrhagic complications from the expanding left axillary hematoma, including bleeding or hematoma expansion.
4. Infection complications, including pneumonia, sepsis, or bacteremia.
5. Cardiovascular complications, including arrhythmias or cardiac arrest, due to the patient's history of atrial fibrillation.
6. Nutritional complications, including malnutrition or electrolyte imbalances, due to the patient's inability to eat or digest food.
7. Psychological complications, including anxiety, depression, or delirium, due to the patient's critical illness and hospitalization.

Based on this information, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to identify any potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent further deterioration of the patient's condition.

   89 yo with PMH of alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis,
   pneumonia, and recent d/c from MICU presents with AMS, elevated INR and
   frank blood from her tracheostomy.
   .
   #1 Respiratory failure: Initial decompensation likely due to diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, although contribution of underlying pneumonia,
   fluid overload, and baseline [**Known lastname **] disease (?) likely contribute.  Of
   note, during prior admission patient was unsuccessfully extubated twice
   and could not be weaned off the vent after several attempts due to high
   RISBIs  and acidemia.  The patient continued to be ventilator dependent
   at her rehab facility and has failed trach mask and low pressure
   support ventilation during this admission b/c of very low tidal volumes
   (down to 130
s) which improved after pressure support was increased
   from 10 to 20. Patient
s air movement also did improve after albuterol
   nebulizer treatment as per nurse.   Lasix boluses d/c at this point b/c
   of rising Cr.  Stenotrophomonis pneumonia treatment course completed 2
   days ago.  Now w/3+GNR in sputum stain, but culture is not complete yet
   and patient is not spiking fevers or having hypotension so will not
   treat at this point.
   - follow sputum culture
   - albuterol/atrovent MDI
   - slow lasix drip to facilitate diuresis
   - PSV trials, continue to try to wean pressure support and peep as
   tolerated
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely related to volume depletion secondary to
   blood loss and up titration of lasix at rehab and in MICU as creatinine
   has trended up over the past week per their records Higher bicarbonate
   level and FeUREA of 34% would support volume depletion as well.  UA
   w/few eos, rare hyaline casts reported.  Did have hematuria, but
   difficult to interpret in setting of indwelling foley, elevated INR,
   and likely UTI. Anti-GBM pending.
   - gentle lasix with PM lytes
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins as possible
   - staghorn R kidney stone noted on CT could be contributing
   .
   # PEG complications:  Erythema/ Pus around peg likely combination of
   dermatitis/skin breakdown from pressure of PEG on skin w/some
   cellulitic component. Initially improved after 3 days on vanco and
   after padded bandage placed between PEG and skin but has worsened over
   last 48 hours with increasingly purulent exudate around the tube.
   Patient also with erosion of gastric wall around PEG site IP evaluated
   - culture exudate
   - Continue vanco for 10day course
 last day of antibiotics [**12-14**]
   - CT showed Peg balloon eroded into gastric wall, likely source of
   melena. Repositioned by IP. OK for meds but not feeds so dobhoff
   inserted.
   .
   # L arm hematoma: Likely due to traumatic picc placement.  Does not
   appear to worsening but will follow closely.  Anterior chest wall mass
   likely a continuation of same process.
   -          warm packs to area
   -          to follow.
   # Blood from trach: Seems from clinical history provided by rehab that
   patient's secretions initially were "blood tinged" and progressed to
   frankly blood over the course of the day on [**12-3**]. Her hematocrit in
   the same time period has decreased from 29-->23.8. Bronchoscopy on
   arrival to the ICU demonstrated bloody secretions which did not clear
   but became progressively bloodier making diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
   most likely diagnosis. However, could also represent lesion near trach
   insertion but this is less likely given bronch findings. Held aspirin
   and coumadin, reversal of INR with  FFP, Vitamin K PO, and then Vitamin
   K IV .  Once INR reversed trach oozing decreased. ANCA negative, anti
   GBM pending.
   - INR 1.4
   - Active T&S, has new PICC for access
   - antiGBM pending
   - f/u blood cx
   - hold aspirin and coumadin
   - ( to keep in mind: per IP given timeline of 2 weeks s/p trach
   consider CT neck to f/u fistula if bleeding does not stop, HCT does not
   stabilize after correction of coags)
   - wean vent as tolerated
   .
   # Anemia: Hct drop x3 since admission. Transfused 3x with 2U of blood.
   Initial drop explained by DAH. Hct did not bump appropriately, found to
   have melena x1 and repeatedly giauac pos stool. Hemolysis labs sent.
   Enlarging hematoma in L arm, axilla,  and anterior chest, but likely
   source of  Hct drop.  Possibility of spontaneous intraperitoneal or
   retroperitoneal hemorrhage r/o with CT abd yesterday
   -  hemolysis labs negative
   -          follow hematoma size
   -          s/p 1 U pRBC  [**Date range (1) 6895**]
   -          Post transfusion Hct, Q12h Hcts
   .
   .
   # Paroxysmal afib: The patient was recently started on coumadin at the
   rehab facility with INR now > 5 on coumadin 5 mg daily. CHADs-2 score
   by my calculation only 1 due to age-not clear that patient has h/o
   hypertension or CHF and no documented h/o stroke or DM.
   - hold coumadin and aspirin
   - consider full dose aspirin for anticoagulation once out of acute
   episode
   - patient typically bradycardic per prior d/c summary, not on rate
   control meds
   .
   # Abdominal distension: NTTP.  Resolved with bowel movement.  Had CXR
   several days ago with what appeared to be a large gas bubble in the
   stomach. Repeat  KUB showed no acute process, LFTs and lipase benign.
   When attempt to draw back on PEG no air noted.  In setting of Hct drop
   and spontaneous alveolar bleeding, CT abd obtained, no evidence of RP
   bleed
   .
   # porcelain gallbladder: noted on CT abd, associated with
   adenocarcinoma 25% of time. [**Month (only) 60**] need further work up out of ICU
   setting.
   .
   # Recent Stenotrophomonas VAP: Bactrim 250 mg IV q8h, stop date [**12-8**]
   per prior d/c summary.
   .
   # Alzheimer's/? altered mental status: Low functioning at baseline.
   Delirium given acute event on top of usual dementia not improving
   situation. To continue home meds when using PEG tube (await KUB
   result).
   .
   # PPx: Increased PPI to [**Hospital1 **], d/c heparin SQ since INR 2.0. Continue
   pneumoboots. Change bowel regimen to prn b/c of diarrhea.
   .
   #FEN: re-start TF as per nutrition.
   .
   # Code: full, family meeting [**12-9**], family considering DNR
   .
   # Access: Right-sided PICC (placed at [**Hospital1 54**] during previous admission).
   To be removed once Left picc placed by IR
   .
   # Communication: With patient and son [**Name (NI) 6287**] [**Known lastname 6767**]([**Telephone/Fax (1) 6768**] cell

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 89-year-old woman with a history of Alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis, pneumonia, and recent discharge from the MICU. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure, acute renal failure, PEG complications, and blood from the tracheostomy.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a diagnosis of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, likely due to the underlying pneumonia, fluid overload, and baseline lung disease. The patient has been on ventilatory support for an extended period and has failed tracheostomy mask and low-pressure support ventilation. The patient's air movement improved after increasing pressure support and albuterol nebulizer treatment.

The patient's renal function is compromised, with a rising creatinine level and a diagnosis of acute renal failure likely related to volume depletion secondary to blood loss and up-titration of lasix. The patient has been transfused with 3 units of blood, and hemolysis labs sent. The patient has a staghorn calculus in the right kidney, which may be contributing to the renal failure.

The patient has a PEG tube complication, with erythema and purulent exudate around the tube site. The patient's hematocrit has decreased significantly, and the patient has melena and guaiac-positive stool. The patient's L arm has a hematoma, likely due to traumatic PICC placement.

The patient's tracheostomy is bleeding, and the patient has been diagnosed with diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. The patient's INR has been reversed with FFP, Vitamin K PO, and IV, and the patient's bleeding has decreased.

The patient has anemia, with a significant drop in hematocrit since admission. The patient has been transfused with 3 units of blood, and hemolysis labs sent. The patient's paroxysmal atrial fibrillation is likely due to the recent start of coumadin, and the patient's CHADS2 score is 1.

The patient has abdominal distension, which has resolved with a bowel movement. The patient has a porcelain gallbladder, which may be associated with adenocarcinoma in 25% of cases.

The patient's recent Stenotrophomonas VAP has been treated with Bactrim, and the patient's antibiotic course has been completed.

The patient's altered mental status is likely due to delirium, given the acute event on top of usual dementia. The patient's home medications will be continued when using the PEG tube.

The patient's code status is DNR, and the family is considering this option. The patient's access is a right-sided PICC, which will be removed once the left PICC is placed by IR.

The patient's nutrition is being provided through Fibersource HN, and glycemic control is being maintained. The patient is at risk for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Continued respiratory failure and need for ventilatory support.
2. Progression of acute renal failure and need for dialysis.
3. Complications from the PEG tube, including infection and bleeding.
4. Continued bleeding from the tracheostomy site.
5. Anemia and need for further transfusions.
6. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and need for anticoagulation.
7. Abdominal distension and potential need for surgical intervention.
8. Porcelain gallbladder and potential need for further workup.
9. Stenotrophomonas VAP and potential need for further antibiotic treatment.
10. Delirium and potential need for further mental status evaluation and treatment.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is recommended that the patient continue to receive close monitoring and management in the ICU, with frequent assessments and adjustments to the patient's treatment plan as needed.

   89 yo with PMH of alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis,
   pneumonia, and recent d/c from MICU presents with AMS, elevated INR and
   frank blood from her tracheostomy.
   .
   #1 Respiratory failure: Initial decompensation likely due to diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, although contribution of underlying pneumonia,
   fluid overload, and baseline [**Known lastname **] disease (?) likely contribute.  Of
   note, during prior admission patient was unsuccessfully extubated twice
   and could not be weaned off the vent after several attempts due to high
   RISBIs  and acidemia.  The patient continued to be ventilator dependent
   at her rehab facility and has failed trach mask and low pressure
   support ventilation during this admission b/c of very low tidal volumes
   (down to 130
s) which improved after pressure support was increased
   from 10 to 20. Patient
s air movement also did improve after albuterol
   nebulizer treatment as per nurse.   Lasix boluses d/c at this point b/c
   of rising Cr.  Stenotrophomonis pneumonia treatment course completed 2
   days ago.  Now w/3+GNR in sputum stain, but culture is not complete yet
   and patient is not spiking fevers or having hypotension so will not
   treat at this point.
   - follow sputum culture
   - albuterol/atrovent MDI
   - slow lasix drip to facilitate diuresis
   - PSV trials, continue to try to wean pressure support and peep as
   tolerated
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely related to volume depletion secondary to
   blood loss and up titration of lasix at rehab and in MICU as creatinine
   has trended up over the past week per their records Higher bicarbonate
   level and FeUREA of 34% would support volume depletion as well.  UA
   w/few eos, rare hyaline casts reported.  Did have hematuria, but
   difficult to interpret in setting of indwelling foley, elevated INR,
   and likely UTI. Anti-GBM pending.
   - gentle lasix with PM lytes
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins as possible
   - staghorn R kidney stone noted on CT could be contributing
   .
   # PEG complications:  Erythema/ Pus around peg likely combination of
   dermatitis/skin breakdown from pressure of PEG on skin w/some
   cellulitic component. Initially improved after 3 days on vanco and
   after padded bandage placed between PEG and skin but has worsened over
   last 48 hours with increasingly purulent exudate around the tube.
   Patient also with erosion of gastric wall around PEG site. Endoscopy by
   IP showed that peg balloon still in stomach, was re-positioned to
   decrease pressure on wall to better allow for healing. No free
   intraperitoneal air was noted on CT.  PEG to gravity, not to be used as
   per ID recommendations.  Surgery consulted by IR to evaluate case.
   - Culture exudate
   - Continue vanco for 10day course
 last day of antibiotics [**12-14**]
   - As per IR recommendations, will re-check CT on Monday or Tuesday to
   eval whether will need surgical removal or can heal on own
   .
   # Positive UA: History of urosepsis with proteus sensitive to unasyn so
   re-started on unasyn while awaiting UCx results.
   -          continue unasyn until UCx resulted
   -          f/u UCx
   .
   # L arm hematoma: Likely due to traumatic picc placement.  Blood
   tracking from area expanding but Hct is stable.
   - warm packs to area
   - follow Hct
   .
   # Blood from trach: Seems from clinical history provided by rehab that
   patient's secretions initially were "blood tinged" and progressed to
   frankly blood over the course of the day on [**12-3**]. Her hematocrit in
   the same time period has decreased from 29-->23.8. Bronchoscopy on
   arrival to the ICU demonstrated bloody secretions which did not clear
   but became progressively bloodier making diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
   most likely diagnosis. However, could also represent lesion near trach
   insertion but this is less likely given bronch findings. Held aspirin
   and coumadin, reversal of INR with  FFP, Vitamin K PO, and then Vitamin
   K IV .  Once INR reversed trach oozing decreased. ANCA negative, anti
   GBM pending.
   - INR 1.4
   - Active T&S
   - antiGBM pending
   - hold aspirin and coumadin
   .
   # Anemia: Hct drop x3 since admission. Transfused 3x with 2U of blood.
   Initial drop explained by DAH. Hct did not bump appropriately, found to
   have melena x1 and repeatedly giauac pos stool. Hemolysis labs
   negative.  Enlarging hematoma in L arm, axilla,  and anterior chest,
   but likely source of  Hct drop.  CT showed no intraperitoneal or
   retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Hct stable today.
   - follow hematoma size
   - follow Hct, transfuse as necessary
   .
   # Paroxysmal afib: The patient was recently started on coumadin at the
   rehab facility with INR now > 5 on coumadin 5 mg daily. CHADs-2 score
   by my calculation only 1 due to age-not clear that patient has h/o
   hypertension or CHF and no documented h/o stroke or DM.
   - hold coumadin and aspirin
   - consider full dose aspirin for anticoagulation once out of acute
   episode
   - patient typically bradycardic per prior d/c summary, not on rate
   control meds
   .
   # Abdominal distension: NTTP.  Has been intermittently present since
   admission. Usually resolves with bowel movement.  LFTs and lipase
   normal. CT w/PEG findings discussed above and porcelain gallbladder,
   but no evidence of intraperitoneal bleed or other intraabdominal
   process.
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need further work up out of ICU setting for finding of porcelain
   gallbladder
   .
   # Alzheimer's/? altered mental status: Low functioning at baseline.
   Delirium given acute event on top of usual dementia not improving
   situation. To continue home meds when using PEG tube (await KUB
   result).
   .

   .

   .
   # Access: L Picc
   .
   # Communication: With patient and son [**Name (NI) 6287**] [**Known lastname 6767**]([**Telephone/Fax (1) 6768**] cell
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 89-year-old woman with a history of Alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis, pneumonia, and recent discharge from the MICU. She is currently in the ICU with a tracheostomy, PEG tube, and PICC line. She has a wide range of medical issues, including respiratory failure, acute renal failure, PEG complications, positive urine culture, and anemia.

Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's initial decompensation was likely due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, but underlying pneumonia, fluid overload, and baseline lung disease may also contribute. She requires continued ventilator support and is at risk for further respiratory deterioration.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine has trended up over the past week, and she has a history of volume depletion secondary to blood loss and up-titration of lasix. She requires gentle lasix with PM lytes, trending of creatinine, and avoidance of nephrotoxins.
3. PEG complications: The patient has erythema and pus around the PEG site, which is likely a combination of dermatitis and skin breakdown from pressure and cellulitic component. She requires continued vancomycin for 10 days, and re-checking of CT on Monday or Tuesday to evaluate whether surgical removal is necessary.
4. Positive urine culture: The patient has a history of urosepsis and has been re-started on ampicillin/sulbactam (Unasyn) pending UCx results.
5. Anemia: The patient has a Hct drop of 3 since admission, which is likely due to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage and enlarging hematoma in the left arm, axilla, and anterior chest. She requires transfusion as necessary and follow-up of hematoma size.
6. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation: The patient has a history of coumadin use at the rehab facility, which has led to an INR > 5. She requires hold of coumadin and aspirin, and consideration of full-dose aspirin for anticoagulation once out of the acute episode.
7. Abdominal distension: The patient has intermittent abdominal distension since admission, which is likely related to bowel movement. She requires further work-up out of the ICU setting for the finding of porcelain gallbladder.
8. Alzheimer's/delirium: The patient has low functioning at baseline and is likely experiencing delirium due to acute events on top of usual dementia. She requires continued home meds when using the PEG tube.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a positive urine culture and is at risk for sepsis, particularly with her underlying pneumonia and PEG complications.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is at risk for further deterioration, particularly with her underlying lung disease and PEG complications.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine has trended up over the past week, and she is at risk for further acute kidney injury with continued lasix use.
4. PEG-related complications: The patient is at risk for further PEG-related complications, including infection, bleeding, and perforation.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is at risk for further worsening, particularly with her ongoing bleeding and transfusion requirements.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's paroxysmal atrial fibrillation is at risk for further cardiac complications, including stroke and heart failure.

   89 yo with PMH of alzheimer's dementia, hypernatremia, urosepsis,
   pneumonia, and recent d/c from MICU presents with AMS, elevated INR and
   frank blood from her tracheostomy.
   .
   #1 Respiratory failure: Initial decompensation likely due to diffuse
   alveolar hemorrhage, although contribution of underlying pneumonia,
   fluid overload, and baseline [**Known lastname **] disease (?) likely contribute.  Of
   note, during prior admission patient was unsuccessfully extubated twice
   and could not be weaned off the vent after several attempts due to high
   RISBIs  and acidemia.  The patient continued to be ventilator dependent
   at her rehab facility and has failed trach mask and low pressure
   support ventilation during this admission b/c of very low tidal volumes
   (down to 130
s) which improved after pressure support was increased
   from 10 to 20. Patient
s air movement also did improve after albuterol
   nebulizer treatment as per nurse.   Lasix boluses previously caused
   rising Cr.  Stenotrophomonis pneumonia treatment course completed.  Now
   w/3+GNR in sputum stain, but culture is not complete yet and patient is
   not spiking fevers or having hypotension so will not treat at this
   point.
   - sputum cult shows Ecoli, suggestive of aspiration
   - albuterol/atrovent MDI
   - increase lasix drip to facilitate diuresis since cr decreasing  and
   UO increasing
   - PSV trials, continue to try to wean pressure support and peep as
   tolerated
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely related to volume depletion secondary to
   blood loss and up titration of lasix at rehab and in MICU as creatinine
   has trended up over the past week per their records Higher bicarbonate
   level and FeUREA of 34% would support volume depletion as well.  UA
   w/few eos, rare hyaline casts reported.  Did have hematuria, but since
   resolved difficult to interpret in setting of indwelling foley,
   elevated INR, and likely UTI. Anti-GBM pending.  Cr now downtrending
   with lasix, perhaps correction of the anemia has improved kidney
   profusion and is allowing further diuresis.
   - lasix gtt with PM lytes
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins as possible
   - staghorn R kidney stone noted on CT could be contributing
   .
   # PEG complications:  Erythema/ Pus around peg likely combination of
   dermatitis/skin breakdown from pressure of PEG on skin w/some
   cellulitic component. Initially improved after starting  vanco and
   after padded bandage placed between PEG and skin but has worsening
   purulent exudate around the tube. Patient also with erosion of gastric
   wall around PEG site. Endoscopy by IP showed that peg balloon still in
   stomach, was re-positioned to decrease pressure on wall to better allow
   for healing. No free intraperitoneal air was noted on CT. [**12-11**] repeat
   EGD showed dobbhoff still post pyloric. Eroson around peg greatly
   improved. PEG ballon in place. No stiches needed.
   - Culture exudate GS shows 2+ GNR, cult pending. Covering with zosyn
   until final cult results as pus is increasing
   - Continue vanco for 10day course for cellulitis

   fluid overload, and baseline [**Known lastname **] disease (?) likely contribute.  Of
   note, during prior admission patient was unsuccessfully extubated twice
   and could not be weaned off the vent after several attempts due to high
   RISBIs  and acidemia.  The patient continued to be ventilator dependent
   at her rehab facility and has failed trach mask and low pressure
   support ventilation during this admission b/c of very low tidal volumes
   (down to 130
s) which improved after pressure support was increased
   from 10 to 20. Patient
s air movement also did improve after albuterol
   nebulizer treatment as per nurse.   Lasix boluses previously caused
   rising Cr.  Stenotrophomonis pneumonia treatment course completed.  Now
   w/3+GNR in sputum stain, but culture is not complete yet and patient is
   not spiking fevers or having hypotension so will not treat at this
   point.
   - sputum cult shows Ecoli, suggestive of aspiration
   - albuterol/atrovent MDI
   - increase lasix drip to facilitate diuresis since cr decreasing  and
   UO increasing
   - PSV trials, continue to try to wean pressure support and peep as
   tolerated
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely related to volume depletion secondary to
   blood loss and up titration of lasix at rehab and in MICU as creatinine
   has trended up over the past week per their records Higher bicarbonate
   level and FeUREA of 34% would support volume depletion as well.  UA
   w/few eos, rare hyaline casts reported.  Did have hematuria, but since
   resolved difficult to interpret in setting of indwelling foley,
   elevated INR, and likely UTI. Anti-GBM pending.  Cr now downtrending
   with lasix, perhaps correction of the anemia has improved kidney
   profusion and is allowing further diuresis.
   - lasix gtt with PM lytes
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins as possible
   - staghorn R kidney stone noted on CT could be contributing
   .
   # PEG complications:  Erythema/ Pus around peg likely combination of
   dermatitis/skin breakdown from pressure of PEG on skin w/some
   cellulitic component. Initially improved after starting  vanco and
   after padded bandage placed between PEG and skin but has worsening
   purulent exudate around the tube. Patient also with erosion of gastric
   wall around PEG site. Endoscopy by IP showed that peg balloon still in
   stomach, was re-positioned to decrease pressure on wall to better allow
   for healing. No free intraperitoneal air was noted on CT. [**12-11**] repeat
   EGD showed dobbhoff still post pyloric. Eroson around peg greatly
   improved. PEG ballon in place. No stiches needed.
   - Culture exudate GS shows 2+ GNR, cult pending. Covering with zosyn
   until final cult results as pus is increasing
   - Continue vanco for 10day course for cellulitis

   tomorrow to confirm PEG placement, dobhoff placement and no free air.
   To re-eval PEG with CT end of week. Plan to restart TF Monday. IP says
   this issue should not keep pt in hospital
   .
   # Positive UA: History of urosepsis with proteus sensitive to unasyn so
   re-started on unasyn while awaiting UCx results.
   -          continue unasyn until UCx resulted
   -          f/u UCx
   .
   # L arm hematoma: Likely due to traumatic picc placement.  Blood
   tracking from area expanding but Hct is stable.
   - warm packs to area
   - follow Hct
   .
   # Blood from trach: Seems from clinical history provided by rehab that
   patient's secretions initially were "blood tinged" and progressed to
   frankly blood over the course of the day on [**12-3**]. Her hematocrit in
   the same time period has decreased from 29-->23.8. Bronchoscopy on
   arrival to the ICU demonstrated bloody secretions which did not clear
   but became progressively bloodier making diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
   most likely diagnosis. However, could also represent lesion near trach
   insertion but this is less likely given bronch findings. Held aspirin

   by my calculation only 1 due to age-not clear that patient has h/o

   # Abdominal distension: NTTP.  Has been intermittently present since

   but no evidence of intraperitoneal bleed or other intraabdominal
